I'm an Interaction Designer with a background in marketing & big data analytics. I transitioned into design because I believe that good experiences need to move beyond data and statistics; they need to be human-centric. I‚Äôm also interested in working with emerging technologies and utilizing their applications to better society. This pushes me to pursue a master‚Äôs degree in Human-Computer Interaction + Design at the University of Washington.

My previous experience in quantitative research helps me find the balance between design thinking and system thinking. This allows me to bridge the gaps between business and design, making sure each design decision is intentional, delightful, and feasible.

I‚Äôm always up for learning new things. My current challenge is coding. I‚Äôve picked up front-end programming and coded this website from scratch in 3 months.

I believe the key to being a good designer is first to be a good person. Kindness matters in design. It‚Äôs the way you carry yourself, the things you‚Äôve done for the community, the people you‚Äôre designing for, and the people you‚Äôre working with.

Traces on Earth

I often ask myself, am I living a life worth remembering?

GRADUATION COMMENCEMENT SPEAKER | 2017

When I was young, my family used to live with less than $2 a day. Growing up with adversity has instilled me with grit, humility, and empathy. Before 5000 people, I walked the crowd through the journey of a 7-year old boy and his life in Saigon, Vietnam.

>> From Red Sox Project to Mayor‚Äôs Office Internship | Suffolk News

>> Du h·ªçc sinh Vi·ªát vinh d·ª± l√† ng∆∞·ªùi duy nh·∫•t ph√°t bi·ªÉu t·ªët nghi·ªáp ƒêH M·ªπ | Yan.vn (in Vietnamese üáªüá≥)

‚ÄúTomorrow we may pursue different careers and have different paths, but don‚Äôt forget where we came from. And we must never lose our kindness and character.‚Äù

EXPANDING A NON-PROFIT | 2015 - 2017

I started the AIESEC Boston chapter and led a team of 25+ members. I facilitated soft skill development workshops, and helped match 28 students with global volunteer opportunities. In 1 year, AIESEC Boston became top 10 chapter in the AIESEC United States network.

>> It takes a ‚ÄòGlobal Village‚Äô to raise a cultured campus. | The Suffolk Journal

>> Boston AIESEC chapter discusses importance of privilege with Suffolk community. |The Suffolk Journal

HELPING LOCAL IMMIGRANTS | 2014 - 2016

After my marketing internship with the Boston Mayor‚Äôs Office as a freshman, I was offered the Ambassador role. I served as a the community leader for Vietnamese immigrants in Dorchester. I facilitated workshops and translated materials to help low-income familities and individuals get access to free government financial services. In 3 years, I helped my community receive over $200k tax credit.

VOLUNTEERING AT AN ORPHANAGE | 2013

In the summer of 2013, I went back to Saigon, Vietnam to volunteer at Hoa Mau Don orphanage. In 3 months, I taught English to kids 5th - 8th grade and served as a translated between the organization and foreign volunteers.

SHARING THE HISTORY OF SEATTLE | 2019

- Project in Progress -
I‚Äôm working with my amazing friends Oliver, Saransh, Tanya, and Trevor from the MHCI+D program on the Seattle Underground project. It‚Äôs a storytelling a AR installation for the Seattle Design Festival coming up on August 24.

Fun Facts
